revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|2006|art}}
The year '''2006 in [[art]]''' involves various significant events.
==Events== *'''Rembrandt 400''': Series of activities to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the birth of [[Rembrandt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rembrandt400.com |publisher=Rembrandt 400 Foundation |title=Program of events |accessdate=17 September 2005 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051026012205/http://www.rembrandt400.com/ |archivedate=26 October 2005 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> *[[1 July]] – [[Mudam]] museum of modern art in [[Luxembourg (city)]], designed by [[I. M. Pei]], is opened by [[Jean, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Jean]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Luxembourg Opens Grand Duke Jean Museum of Modern Art |first=Alan |last=Riding |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/08/arts/design/08pei.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=8 July 2006 |accessdate=27 June 2011}}</ref> *[[31 August]] – The stolen [[Edvard Munch]] paintings ''[[The Scream]]'' and ''[[Madonna (Edvard Munch)|Madonna]]'' are recovered in a police raid in [[Oslo, Norway]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Munch paintings recovered |date=31 August 2006 |publisher=Aftenposten |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1441444.ece |accessdate=22 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219221013/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1441444.ece |archivedate=19 February 2008 |df= }}</ref> *[[17 November]] – The [[Metropolitan Borough of Bury]] in [[England]] sells its [[L. S. Lowry]] painting [http://www.ls-lowry.com/work/arb47.html ''A River Bank'' (1947)] (bought in 1951 for £150) for £1.25 million at a [[Christie's]] auction to a private buyer to help fund a £10 million budget deficit.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/6157204.stm|work=[[BBC News]]|title=Council's Lowry sold for £1.25m|date=17 November 2006|accessdate=2011-07-22}}</ref>
==Awards== *[[Archibald Prize]] – [[Marcus Wills]], ''The Paul Juraszek Monolith'' *[[Beck's Futures]] – [[Matt Stokes]], ''Long After Tonight'' *[[Caldecott Medal]] – [[Chris Raschka]], ''[[The Hello, Goodbye Window]]'' *[[Hugo Boss Prize]] – [[Tacita Dean]] *[[Turner Prize]] – [[Tomma Abts]] *[[Wynne prize]] – [[John Beard (artist)|John Beard]], ''The Gap''
==Exhibitions== *''The Masterpieces'' [[Rijksmuseum]], [[Amsterdam]], Jan 2 – Dec 31, 2006 *''All the Rembrandts'', Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam Jan 26 – Dec 31, 2006 *''Rembrandt – Caravaggio'' [[Van Gogh Museum]] in cooperation with the Rijksmuseum, Feb 24 – Jun 18, 2006 *''A summer with Rembrandt'' [[Mauritshuis]], [[The Hague]], Jun 26 – Sep 18, 2006 *''Rembrandt, the Etcher'' The Rembrandt House Museum, Amsterdam, Jul 8 – Sep 3, 2006 *''[[Auguste Rodin|Rodin]]'' ([[Royal Academy of Arts]], London, 23 Sep 2006—1 Jan 2007) *''Everyone Sang: a view of [[Siegfried Sassoon]] and his world by 25 contemporary painters'' (Francis Kyle Gallery, London, November–December) *[[Peter Prendergast (artist)|Peter Prendergast]] retrospective, Oriel Ynys Môn, 14 Jan – 26 Feb 2006 (toured throughout UK) * [[Barely Legal (Banksy)|"Barely Legal" (Banksy)]]
==Works== {{See also|Category:2006 paintings|Category:2006 sculptures}} * Magdalena Abakanowicz - [[Agora (sculpture)|Agora]], [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]], [[Chicago, Illinois]], [[United States]] * Gary Breeze – [[Bali Bombings Memorial, London]] * Ed Carpenter – ''[[Tecotosh]]'' (sculpture, Portland, Oregon) * Brian Goldbloom – ''[[Festival Lanterns]]'' (sculpture, Portland, Oregon) * [[Dan Graham]] – ''[[For Gordon Bunshaft]]'' (sculpture, Washington, D.C.) * [[David Hockney]] ** ''[http://www.hockneypictures.com/exhibitions/la.louver.march2007/yorkshire.02.php Woldgate Woods, March 30 - April 21 2006]'' ** ''[http://www.hockneypictures.com/exhibitions/la.louver.march2007/yorkshire.13.php Woldgate Woods, 6 & 9 November 2006]'' * Mel Katz – ''[[Daddy Long Legs (sculpture)|Daddy Long Legs]]'' (sculpture, Portland, Oregon) * [[Gopal Swami Khetanchi]] ** ''Bani-Thani'' ** ''Devashree'' * [[Frank Meisler]] – ''[[Kindertransport – The Arrival]]'' (sculpture, London) * ''[[Lovejoy Columns]]'' (sculpture, Portland, Oregon)
==Deaths==
===January to March=== *[[1 January]] – [[John Latham (artist)|John Latham]], Zambian [[conceptual artist]] (b.[[1921 in art|1921]]) *[[8 January]] – [[Mimmo Rotella]], Italian artist and poet (b.[[1918 in art|1918]]) *[[14 January]] – [[Jim Gary]], American sculptor (b.[[1939 in art|1939]]) *[[29 January]] – [[Nam June Paik]], South Korean-born American [[video art]]ist (b.[[1932 in art|1932]]) *[[15 February]] – [[Joash Woodrow]], English artist (b.[[1927 in art|1927]]) *[[23 February]] – [[Mauri Favén]], Finnish painter (b.[[1920 in art|1920]]) *[[4 March]] **<!--4 March-->[[David Rose (animator)|David Rose]], American animator (b.[[1910 in art|1910]]) **<!--4 March-->[[Edgar Valter]], [[Estonia]]n writer and illustrator of children's books (b.[[1929 in art|1929]]) *[[9 March]] – [[Jean Leymarie (art historian)|Jean Leymarie]], French [[art historian]] (b.[[1919 in art|1919]]) *[[25 March]] – [[Bob Carlos Clarke]], Irish photographer (b.[[1950 in art|1950]]) *[[27 March]] – [[Ian Hamilton Finlay]], Scottish poet, writer, artist and gardener (b.[[1925 in art|1925]]) *[[28 March]] – [[Pro Hart]], Australian painter (b.[[1928 in art|1928]])
===April to June=== *[[5 April]] – [[Allan Kaprow]], American painter, [[Assemblage (art)|assemblagist]] and art theorist (b.[[1927 in art|1927]]) *[[23 April]] – [[Isaac Witkin]], South African sculptor (b.[[1936 in art|1936]]) *[[3 May]] – [[Karel Appel]], Dutch painter, sculptor and poet (b.[[1921 in art|1921]]) *[[8 May]] – [[Iain Macmillan]], Scottish photographer (b.[[1938 in art|1938]]) *[[9 May]] – [[Edouard Jaguer]], French poet and [[art critic]] (b.[[1924 in art|1924]]) *[[27 May]] – [[Alex Toth]], American comic book artist and cartoonist (b.[[1928 in art|1928]])
===July to December=== *[[8 July]] – [[Catherine Leroy]], French photographer (b.[[1945 in art|1945]]) *[[15 July]] – [[Andrée Ruellan]], American painter (b.[[1905 in art|1905]]) *[[28 July]] – [[Richard Mock]], American painter, sculptor and cartoonist (b.[[1944 in art|1944]]) *[[1 August]] **[[Jason Rhoades]], American [[installation art]]ist (b.[[1965 in art|1965]]) **[[Bob Thaves]], American illustrator (b.[[1924 in art|1924]]) *[[4 August]] – [[Julio Galán]], Mexican artist (b.[[1958 in art|1958]]) *[[20 August]] – [[Joe Rosenthal]], American [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning photographer (b.[[1911 in art|1911]]) *[[26 August]] – [[Vladimir Tretchikoff]], Russian artist (b.[[1913 in art|1913]]) *[[1 September]] – Sir [[Kyffin Williams]], Welsh landscape painter (b.[[1918 in art|1918]]) *[[17 October]] – [[Marcia Tucker]], American museum curator (b.[[1940 in art|1940]]) *[[26 November]] – [[Dave Cockrum]], American [[comic book]] artist (b.[[1943 in art|1943]]) *[[6 December]] – [[Robert Rosenblum]], American Art Historian (b.[[1927 in art|1927]]) *[[16 December]] – [[Larry Zox]], American painter and printmaker (b.[[1937 in art|1937]]) *[[18 December]] – [[Ruth Bernhard]], American photographer (b.[[1905 in art|1905]])
==References== {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} '''Andretta''' is a village and an [[artists' colony]] in [[Himachal Pradesh]]. The artists' colony was established in the 1920s, when Irish theatre artiste and environmentalist, [[Norah Richards]], shifted here from Lahore. Near [[Palampur]] in the [[Kangra District]], with [[Dhauladhar]] range of the Himalayas as a backdrop, Andretta over the years has attracted many noted artists, theatre practitioners, painters and more recently potters. Two of the people who became associated with it early on were painters [[Sobha Singh (painter)|Sobha Singh]] and [[B. C. Sanyal]].<ref name=toi13/>
==History==
Norah, an actress originally from Ireland, married Philip Richards, who was a professor at [[Government College, Lahore]]. She arrived in [[Lahore]], an important cultural centre, in 1908. She later became vice-principal at [[Dayal Singh College, Lahore]].
In the following years, she played a pivotal role in establishing modern [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] theatre, staging plays with Punjabi themes. After the death of her husband, she went back briefly, only to return in 1924, when she made Andretta, a village near Palampur, her home. She built a traditional Kangra-style mud house, known as ‘Chameli Niwas’, employing local style and material, using mud, slate and bamboo. She also built a makeshift proscenium and invited Punjabi theatre amateurs and professionals to perform plays.<ref name=tri02>{{cite web| title =Fragrant memories of Norah Richard’s Chameli Niwas|author=Charu Dogra |publisher=The Tribune| url = http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020413/windows/main5.htm |date= 13 April 2002| accessdate = 2014-02-17 }}</ref><ref name=out/>
In 1935, the District Commissioner of Kangra gave Richards 15 acres of land, and the Woodland Estate came into existence. She started a school of drama, and in time the village was known as "Mem-da-pind" (Village of [[Sahib#Colonial and modern use|Memsahib]]).
In its early days, travel to the village was not easy. It took a 12-hour train journey, followed by a bus ride, and the last nine miles from [[Banuri (village)|Banuri]] (the nearest village) were covered on foot. Even so, it started attracting artists from all over, especially Lahore.
This included painter [[B. C. Sanyal]] and professor Jai Dayal Singh, a pupil of Philip Richards from [[Lahore University]], through the 1940s. Sanyal started organizing painting exhibitions to fund the Norah Centre for Arts and a resort. Noted painter, [[Sobha Singh (painter)|Sobha Singh]], most known for making Sikh religious painting, moved in and stayed here till his death in 1986.<ref name=tri02/><ref name=out>{{cite web|title=Andretta Artists' Village: The Irish Lahorian |author=Charu Soni |url=http://traveller.outlookindia.com/destination.aspx?id=569&id1=2 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715024357/http://traveller.outlookindia.com/destination.aspx?id=569&id1=2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-15 |accessdate=2014-02-17 |publisher=Outlook Traveller }}</ref> Richards nurtured Punjabi theatre through the 1940s and 1960s, and came to be known as the "grandmother of Punjabi theatre."<ref>{{cite web| title = PU writers’ home at Andretta |publisher=The Tribune, Chandigarh| url = http://www.tribuneindia.com/2000/20000711/himachal.htm#2|date= 11 July 2000|accessdate = 2014-02-18 }}</ref>
Further on, Gurucharan Singh, a noted potter who started the Delhi Blue Pottery in the 1952, established base here. Active till the end, he died in 1995 at the age of 99.<ref>{{cite web | title = This above all: Master potter|publisher=The Tribune| url = http://www.tribuneindia.com/1998/98nov14/saturday/aboveall.htm|date= 14 November 1998| accessdate = 2014-02-17}}</ref> [[Freda Bedi]], mother of actor [[Kabir Bedi]], who converted to Buddhism, lived at the village for a while.<ref name=toi13/>
[[File:Andretta pottery at Dastkar Bazaar, Delhi.jpg|thumb|Andretta pottery at [[Dastkar]] Bazaar, Delhi.]] In 1983, Mansimran "Mini" Singh, son of noted potter Gurcharan Singh, and his wife Mary Singh moved here and started Andretta Pottery and Craft Society with a production studio which produces earthen slipware and a terracotta museum. They set up a Central Government Rural Marketing Centre with a grant of Rs 1,35,000 to provide assistance to potters. The society runs three-month-long residential courses for potters. Today, pottery from Andretta is sold at outlets across India.<ref name=toi13>{{cite web | title = Himachal's pot secret | url = http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-07-04/travel/38528897_1_himachal-pradesh-malana-hptdc |date=4 July 2013| accessdate = 2014-02-16 |pages=1–2| publisher = The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = Andretta-A sanctuary of potters |publisher=The Hindu| url = http://www.hindu.com/2004/07/30/stories/2004073006550300.htm|date= 30 Jul 2004| accessdate = 2014-02-18 }}</ref>
Later in life, Richards was made a fellow by the [[Punjabi University]] in [[Patiala]], while in turn she willed her house and land around it to the university. Today, the estate of [[Norah Richards]] has been renovated and maintained by the university. Each year on her birthday, 29 October, a Punjabi theatre festival is hosted by the students.<ref>{{cite book|title=Handbook of Universities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rs-jsaPenxYC&pg=PA696|year=2006|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Dist|isbn=978-81-269-0608-6|page=696}}</ref><ref name=clay13>{{cite web| title = Clay and Sky |publisher= The Indian Express| url = http://indianexpress.com/article/news-archive/web/clay-and-sky/# |author=Aditi Banerjee |date=21 April 2013| accessdate = 2014-02-18 }}</ref>
==Tourism== Andretta has become a popular tourist attraction of the region. Nearby is [[Bir, Himachal Pradesh|Bir-Billing]], a paragliding destination.<ref name=clay13/> There are some [[homestay]]s catering to the tourists, otherwise regular accommodations are available at Palampur, a popular tourist destination.<ref name=out/><ref name="Jreat2004">{{cite book|author=Manoj Jreat|title=Tourism in Himachal Pradesh|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n6Qa0OrXstAC&pg=PA129|year=2004|publisher=Indus Publishing|isbn=978-81-7387-157-3|page=129}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Homestays in Kangra |publisher=Himachal Tourism |url=http://himachaltourism.gov.in/post/homestays-in-kangra.aspx |accessdate=2014-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223104115/http://himachaltourism.gov.in/post/homestays-in-kangra.aspx |archivedate=23 February 2014 }}</ref>
===Visitors' attractions===
* Andretta Pottery and Craft Society * Norah Richard's House * Norah Richard's Centre for the Arts * Sir Sobha Singh Art Gallery
==Transport== Andretta is situated 20-minute drive or 13 km away from [[Palampur]] on the road towards [[Mandi, Himachal Pradesh]]. [[Dharamshala]] is at a distance of 48 km from Andretta. Nearest railway station is [[Pathankot Junction railway station|Pathankot]], 120 km away as is the [[Pathankot Airport]].<ref name=toi13/>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book|author=Anupa Lal|title=Pottery and the Legacy of Sardar Gurcharan Singh|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iXIIAgAACAAJ|date=1998|publisher=Delhi Blue Pottery Trust|isbn=978-81-900931-0-1}}
==External links== * {{cite web | title = Andretta in Himachal's Kangra valley |publisher=[[India TV ]]| url = http://www.indiatvnews.com/print/news/wanna-witness-beautiful-art-visit-andretta-in-himachal-19422-1.html }} * [http://www.andrettapottery.com/index.html Andretta Pottery, website]
{{Coord|32.0639|N|76.563|E|display=title}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Antwerp Jazz Club | native_name = Antwerpse Jazzclub | native_name_lang = nld | named_after = The city of [[Antwerp]] | image = A sculpture resembling the logo of the Antwerp Jazz Club, attached to the front of the foldable wooden screen covering the presenter's area (13 September 2016).jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = A sculpture resembling the logo of the Antwerp Jazz Club, attached to the front of the foldable wooden screen covering the presenter's area, present during the jazz club's Tuesday-evening sessions in its clubhouse (13 September 2016). | caption = A sculpture resembling the logo of the Antwerp Jazz Club, attached to the front of the foldable wooden screen covering the presenter's area, present during the jazz club's Tuesday-evening sessions in its clubhouse (13 September 2016). | logo = Logo_of_the_Antwerp_Jazz_Club_(Dutch,_'Antwerpse_Jazz_Club';_abbreviated_'AJC')_(13_September_2016).png | logo_size = 85px | logo_alt = The logo of the Antwerp Jazz Club, as retrieved in 2016. The logo depicts the abbreviation of the club (AJC), while a saxophone takes on the shape of the middle letter "J". | logo_caption = The logo of the Antwerp Jazz Club, as retrieved in 2016. The logo depicts the abbreviation of the club (AJC), while a [[saxophone]] takes on the shape of the middle letter "J". | formation = {{start date and age|1938}}, making it one of the oldest still existing [[jazz club]]s. | founder = Hans Philippi | location = Marc Vanistendael, August Van de Wielelei 305, bus 8, 2100 [[Deurne, Belgium]]. '''(Secretary)'''{{cite web|url=http://www.jazzinbelgium.com/venue/id=611?lang=nl|title=Antwerpse Jazz Club|access-date=13 September 2016|publisher=Lundis d'Hortense}} | coords =
* '''Clubhouse:''' {{Coord|51|13|17.8|N|4|23|58.9|E}} * '''Secretary:''' {{Coord|51|13|10.7|N|4|28|50.9|E}} | region = [[Flanders]], Belgium | headquarters = Second floor of Café Den Bengel, [[Grote Markt (Antwerp)|Grote Markt]] 5, 2000 [[Antwerp]], Belgium. '''(Clubhouse)''' {{see also|#Location}} | website =
* '''Currently:''' {{Official URL}} {{URL|http://www.AntwerpseJazzClub.com|AntwerpseJazzClub.com}} {{Nl icon}} * '''Previously (archived):''' {{URL|https://web.archive.org/web/20101219173015/http://www.AntwerpseJazzClub.be/|AntwerpseJazzClub.be}} {{Nl icon}} | purpose = ''"The study and propaganda of the jazz-music, as it was created and played by the [[African Americans|Afro-Americans]] of the United States, by means of the exemplified listening of music- and image recordings, through lectures at third parties about the nature and movements of jazz and, if feasible the organizing of concerts with American jazz musicians."'' | key_people =
* Marc Vanistendael; * Josée Lissens; and * Language professor Piet Van De Craen }} The '''Antwerp Jazz Club''' ({{lang-nl|Antwerpse Jazzclub}}, abbreviated '''AJC''') is an association in [[Antwerp]], Belgium, founded in 1938{{cite web|url=http://www.lionelhampton.nl/antwerpsejazzclub.html|title=Antwerpse Jazz Club|author=Hans Bebop Bonefaas|date=16 April 2014|access-date=12 September 2016}} by Hans Philippi,{{cite web|url=http://www.antwerpsejazzclub.com/index.php?page=club|title=De Club|publisher=Antwerpse Jazz Club|access-date=12 September 2016}} which delivers weekly lectures about and presentations of [[jazz]] music,{{cite magazine|url=https://issuu.com/webredactie/docs/dp_60936_verenigingengids_district_antwerpen201021/9|page=16|title=Verenigingen. Gids. District Antwerpen|date=2010–2011|first1=Femke|last1=Syvertsen|first2=Kelly|last2=Stark|first3=Ann|last3=Melis|publisher=Jos Bergmans|id=Wettelijk Depotnummer D/2009/0306/320|location=[[Antwerp]]|department=District Antwerpen (Stad Antwerpen)}} at no cost, open to the public at large. Its sessions are held in Dutch. Other than these sessions, the club organizes concerts, including helping to organize [[blues]] concerts; and has aided in the screenings of jazz documentaries. Its Tuesday-sessions are held mostly by a member, and if not by another amateur of jazz, and are often illustrated by DVD-recordings. They are held every Tuesday night from 20PM until 22PM, but not during the [[Christmas]] period, nor the month of July. On request, the association also organises events about jazz for interested associations. The [[jazz club]] is a member of: * "De Stedelijke Culturele Raad van Antwerpen" (an advisory body which features civil participation in culture-related policy of the city of Antwerp{{cite web|url=https://www.antwerpen.be/nl/info/stedelijke-cultuurraad|title=Stedelijke cultuurraad|publisher=Stad Antwerpen [City of Antwerp]|date=18 September 2014|access-date=12 September 2016}}); * [[Hot Club de France]]; and * Centre for Black Music Research, [[Chicago]], United States. The now obsolete Dutch-language website Gratisinantwerpen.be, which was supported by the city of Antwerp and listed free events in Antwerp (the website also had a less complete English version at Antwerpforfree.be), used to advertise the weekly Tuesday-sessions of the ''AJC''.{{cite web|url=http://gratisinantwerpen.be/ |date=14 February 2014 |archive-date=2014-02-14 |access-date=13 September 2016 |title=ALLES WAT GRATIS IS DEZE WEEK / ALL THE FREE EVENTS THIS WEEK |publisher=Guerilla vzw |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214164758/http://gratisinantwerpen.be/ |df= }} ''AJC'' is a subscriber to a number of jazz magazines, from the United States and from several European countries, which can be consulted in its clubhouse. == History == [[File:Guy Van Looy presenting his multimedia blues presentation entitled 'Portraits in Blues 57; Het SPIVEY PLATENLABEL' (meaning The SPIVEY RECORD LABEL) at the Antwerp Jazz Club (AJC) (13 September 2016).jpg|thumb|Guy Van Looy presenting his multimedia blues presentation entitled "Portraits in Blues 57: The SPIVEY RECORD LABEL" at the Antwerp Jazz Club (AJC) on 13 September 2016. Marc Vanistendael can be seen in the far left of the picture.]] In 1938, the club started as gatherings to listen to commented jazz music, which remains the main activity of the club today (info {{as of|lc=y|2016}}). Since 1950, the club also started organizing concerts. Among the famous jazz musicians who have performed in Antwerp in the 1950s and 1960s, due to the ''AJC'', are: [[Willie "The Lion" Smith]], [[Big Bill Broonzy]], [[Earl Hines]], [[Memphis Slim]], [[Buck Clayton]], [[Bill Coleman]], [[Buddy Tate]], [[Ben Webster]], [[Illinois Jacquet]], [[Ray Bryant]] and [[Guy Lafitte]].{{cite magazine|url=https://issuu.com/jazzmozaiek/docs/jm0801_vol_web/21|editor1=Luc De Baefs|editor2=Bernard Lefèvre|publisher=Muziekmozaïek vzw|year=2008|issue=1|page=21|magazine=Muziekmozaïek|first=Bernard|last=Lefèvre|title=Antwerpse Jazzclub 70! "Doordringen tot de essentie van de jazz"}} On 28 April 1963 the ''AJC'' celebrated its [[silver jubilee]]. The "Archive of Fons Van Cleempoel" (an archive spanning the years 1968—1988, created by "{{ill|Amsab - Institute for Social History|nl|Amsab-Instituut voor Sociale Geschiedenis}}", in partnership with the "European Holocaust Research Infrastructure (EHRI)" and the "National Archives of Belgium"){{cite web|url=https://portal.ehri-project.eu/units/be-002143-be_amsab_isg_505|title=Archief van Fons Van Cleempoel|id=BE / Amsab-ISG / 505|access-date=13 September 2016|publisher=European Holocaust Research Infrastructure (EHRI)}} entails some documents from the ''AJC''.{{cite report|url=ftp://digital.amsab.be/finding_aids/finding_aid_BE_AMSAB_505.pdf|id=S/1988/505, S/2000/527, S/2011/507|title=Plaatsingslijst van het archief van Fons Van Cleempoel (1968-1988)|publisher=Amsab - Instituut voor Sociale Geschiedenis}} On the club's seventy-year jubilee, the club honoured its own history by means of showing its own concert recordings, lengthy documentation and imagery during its Tuesday-sessions. On 18 August 2016, the Antwerp cinema "Cinema Zuid" (the new name of the Antwerp "Filmmuseum" since 12 September 2009, after it had moved to the Antwerp district "[[Zuid, Antwerp|South]]" in 2004 under the [[Museum of Modern Art, Antwerp|Museum of Contemporary Art in Antwerp]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemazuid.be/nl/contacteer|title=Over Cinema Zuid|access-date=13 September 2016|website=Cinema Zuid}} in collaboration with the ''AJC'', organized a screening of two documentaries about the Belgian jazz musician and [[Conducting|conductor]] [[Stan Brenders]] and about the jazz guitarist [[Django Reinhardt]] respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemazuid.be/nl/film/manneken-swing-swing-guitar-genius-django-reinhardt|title=MANNEKEN SWING + SWING GUITAR: THE GENIUS OF DJANGO REINHARDT|publisher=Cinema Zuid|access-date=13 September 2016}} == Location == [[File:Protected_monuments_in_Antwerp_'Ambachtshuis_de_Mouwe'_(alternative_names;_'de_gulde_Mouwe'_or_'het_Cuypershuys'_in_the_center,_and_at_its_left;_'Burgerhuis_Witten_Engel',_and_at_its_right;_'Huis_Spaengien'_(13_September_2016,_19;45PM).jpg|thumb|The clubhouse of ''AJC'' is located on the second floor (where windows can be seen opened) of the building in the centre (Ambachtshuis de Mouwe), a protected monument. Picture taken on 13 September 2016, fifteen minutes before the 8PM Tuesday-session of the jazz club.]] Since 8 November 1994, ''AJC'' holds its sessions in a bar called "Den Bengel" in Antwerp.{{cite web|url=http://www.denbengel.be/Jazz_New.html|website=Cafe Den Bengel|title=Verenigingen gevestigd in "Den Bengel". ANTWERPSE JAZZCLUB|date=27 February 2016|access-date=12 September 2016}} More precisely, the clubhouse of ''AJC'' is housed in the same building as that bar (which occupies the ground floor), yet on the second floor. The building is actually an old [[guildhall|guild house]] ({{lang-nl|ambachtshuis}}) called "Ambachtshuis de Mouwe" (alternative names: "de gulde Mouwe" or "het Cuypershuys"), which is registered and protected as a monument since 2 September 1976 into the Flemish inventary of [[immovable property]], part of the [[heritage registers in Belgium]].{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4034|title=Ambachtshuis de Mouwe. inventaris bouwkundig erfgoed \ bouwkundig relict|id=4034|publisher=Onroerend Erfgoed (Flemish Government)|access-date=14 September 2016}} The building's ground floor is dated 1579, its [[gable]] is dated 1628. The building was originally the "house" of the [[craft]] of [[cooper (profession)|cooperage]] ({{lang-nl|kamer van het Kuipersambacht}}). The architectural style of the building is [[renaissance architecture]], it was designed by Léonard Blomme, and restaured in 1907. The top of the building is crowned with a triangular [[pediment]] which holds a gilded statue of [[Saint Matthias]], the [[patron saint]] of the coopers. The building is part of the square [[Grote Markt (Antwerp)|Grote Markt]]. When facing its [[facade|façade]], one finds the building [https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4033 Burgerhuis Witten Engel] {{Nl icon}} at its left and the building [https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4035 Huis Spaengien] {{Nl icon}} at its right, which are also protected monuments.{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4033|title=Burgerhuis Witten Engel. inventaris bouwkundig erfgoed \ bouwkundig relict|id=4033|publisher=Onroerend Erfgoed (Flemish Government)|access-date=14 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4035|title=Huis Spaengien. inventaris bouwkundig erfgoed \ bouwkundig relict|id=4035|publisher=Onroerend Erfgoed (Flemish Government)|access-date=14 September 2016}} == Notable persons == One of its board members is Piet Van De Craen,{{cite web|title=antwerpse jazz club |website=willy's blog |access-date=13 September 2016 |archive-url=https://blog.seniorennet.be/cowboy/tvblog.php?startaantal=5 |url=https://blog.seniorennet.be/cowboy/tvblog.php?startaantal=5 |archive-date=24 August 2016 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} a full-time{{cite web|url=http://research.vub.ac.be/food-history/piet-van-de-craen|publisher=[[Vrije Universiteit Brussel]]|access-date=13 September 2016|series=Research > Social & Cultural Food Studies|title=Piet Van De Craen}} language professor of Dutch Linguistics and of General Linguistics at the [[Vrije Universiteit Brussel]],{{cite news|url=http://www.vrijzinnigwestvlaanderen.be/deze-maand/evenementdetail/904/-/jazz-koksijde3-0-met-piet-van-de-craen|title=Jazz@Koksijde3.0 met Piet van de Craen|publisher=Vrijzinnig West-Vlaanderen|first=Marc|last=Van Muylen|location=VOC de koepel, Westhoek, Houtsaegerlaan 21, 8670 Koksijde, Belgium|date=4 October 2015}} who has been called a major force behind the jazz club. For the occasion of the seventy-year jubilee of the ''AJC'' in 2008, Piet Van De Craen published a monograph about [[Duke Ellington]] (the first ever publication about him in Dutch) which features a concise biography and discography, looks at Ellington as a pianist/composer and at Ellington's co-operation with [[Billy Strayhorn]] and "The Ellingtonians" before and after 1943. In the same year, Piet Van De Craen also criticized the lack of references to jazz history in the United States: {{quote|text=The United States doesn't learn anything from the history. Everytime there is a new president, one starts all over again. It is a country where connections are not made. And then it happens that, for example with [[Oscar Peterson]], recently died, the press doesn't make any reference to [[Art Tatum]], just as if Peterson arose out of nowhere ... that kind of profundity is lacking.}} === Presidents === ==== Hans Philippi ==== Hans Philippi (born 17 December 1905) founded both the ''AJC'', as well as the ''Hot Club Basel'', a jazz club in [[Basel]], Switzerland. He was an early advocate of the recognition of jazz as an art. He had his own radio series, held jazz music presentations by means of playing sound records throughout Switzerland and was acquainted with jazz musicians such as [[Louis Armstrong]] and jazz experts such as [[Hugues Panassié]] and [[Charles Delaunay]].{{cite report|url=http://www.jazzdocumentation.ch/mario/philippi/1einleitung.pdf|date=24 March 2006|title=Jazz in der Schweiz 1924-1976. Zeitdokumente des Hans Philippi aus Basel. Das Verzeichnis|chapter=Einleitung|author=Mario Schneeberger|access-date=12 September 2016|website=JAZZdocumentation.ch}} The Swiss jazz musician Mario Schneeberger compiled a list of notable documents regarding Hans Philippi, from the memorial albums of Philippi, after an acquaintance of Schneeberger had told him that they were about to be put up as garbage disposal following a [[house clearance]] in February 2004. In this archive by Mario Schneeberger, it is noted that Hans Philippi was president of the ''AJC'' in 1938, as from a booklet of that year produced by the ''AJC'' called "Jazz-Leven".{{cite report|url=http://www.jazzdocumentation.ch/mario/philippi/3orte.pdf|date=24 March 2006|title=Jazz in der Schweiz 1924-1976. Zeitdokumente des Hans Philippi aus Basel. Das Verzeichnis|chapter=Orte|author=Mario Schneeberger|access-date=12 September 2016|website=JAZZdocumentation.ch}} ==== Louis Vaes and François Vaes ==== The activities of the club were coordinated by Louis Vaes (1920—1998) from 1946 until 1998. Later, his brother François Vaes (born 1939), nicknamed "Sus",{{cite web|url=http://www.muziekmozaiek.be/index.php?action=nieuwsdetail&nieuws=2336&titel=Antwerpse+Jazz+Club+in+rouw&select_onderdeel=4090|title=Antwerpse Jazz Club in rouw|series=JAZZ. Jazzweblog|publisher=Muziekmozaïek|date=12 August 2012|access-date=12 September 2016}} became president of the club, until he died after a "short disease" on 9 August 2012. François Vaes advocated for youths to appreciate the roots of jazz, as opposed to being seemingly merely interested in new or trendy jazz music. ==See also== * [[Jazz in Belgium]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official|http://www.antwerpsejazzclub.com/}} {{nl icon}} * {{cite web|url= http://www.muziekmozaiek.be/demo_muzmoz/files/File/download/JM_edities/JM801/JM81_AJC.pdf |title=Article in the Flemish jazz magazine "Jazzmozaïek" about the celebration of the 70-year existence of the jazz club }} {{small|(129 KB)}} {{Nl icon}} [[Category:Jazz clubs in Belgium]] [[Category:Antwerp]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:Jazz organizations]] [[Category:Belgian jazz]] [[Category:Jazz culture]]

revision.comment: /* Types of elicited emotions */
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=July 2013}}
In [[psychology of art]], the relationship between '''art and emotion''' has newly been the subject of extensive study thanks to the intervention of esteemed art historian [[Alexander Nemerov]]. [[Emotion]]al or aesthetic responses to [[art]] have previously been viewed as basic stimulus response, but new theories and research have suggested that these experiences are more complex and able to be studied experimentally.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart>{{cite journal|last=Silvia|first=Paul J.|title=Emotional Responses to Art: From Collation and Arousal to Cognition and Emotion.|journal=Review of General Psychology|date=1 January 2005|volume=9|issue=4|pages=342–357|doi=10.1037/1089-2680.9.4.342}}</ref> Emotional responses are often regarded as the keystone to experiencing art, and the creation of an emotional experience has been argued as the purpose of artistic expression.<ref name=Fellous-review>{{cite journal|last=Fellous|first=Jean-Marc|title=A mechanistic view of the expression and experience of emotion in the arts. Deeper that reason: Emotion and its role in literature, music and art by Jenefer Robinson|journal=The American Journal of Psychology|year=2006|volume=119|issue=4|pages=668–674|doi=10.2307/20445371}}</ref> Research has shown that the neurological underpinnings of perceiving art differ from those used in standard object recognition.<ref name=Cupchick-neuro>{{cite journal|last=Cupchik|first=Gerald C.|author2=Vartanian, Oshin|author3= Crawley, Adrian|author4= Mikulis, David J.|title=Viewing artworks: Contributions of cognitive control and perceptual facilitation to aesthetic experience|journal=Brain and Cognition|date=1 June 2009|volume=70|issue=1|pages=84–91|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2009.01.003}}</ref> Instead, [[brain]] regions involved in the experience of emotion and goal setting show activation when viewing art.<ref name=Cupchick-neuro />
== Basis for Emotional Responses to Art == Evolutionary ancestry has hard-wired humans to have affective responses for certain patterns and traits. These predispositions lend themselves to responses when looking at certain visual arts as well. Identification of subject matter is the first step in understanding the visual image. Being presented with visual stimuli creates initial confusion. Being able to comprehend a figure and background creates closure and triggers the pleasure centers of the brain by remedying the confusion. Once an image is identified, meaning can be created by accessing memory relative to the visual stimuli and associating personal memories with what is being viewed.<ref name="barry">{{cite journal | last1 = Barry | first1 = A | year = 2006 | title = Perceptual Aesthetics: Transcendent Emotion, Neurological Image | url = | journal = Visual Communication Quarterly | volume = 13 | issue = 3| pages = 134–151 | doi = 10.1207/s15551407vcq1303_2 }}</ref>
Other methods of stimulating initial interest that can lead to emotion involves pattern recognition. [[Symmetry]] is often found in works of art, and the human brain unconsciously searches for symmetry for a number of reasons. Potential predators were [[Symmetry in biology|bilaterally symmetrical]], as were potential prey. Bilateral symmetry also exists in humans, and a healthy human is typically symmetrical. This attraction to symmetry was therefore advantageous, as it helped humans recognize danger, food, and mates. Art containing symmetry therefore is typically approached and positively valenced to humans.<ref name="barry" />
Another example is to observe paintings or photographs of bright, open landscapes that often evoke a feeling of beauty, [[Relaxation (psychology)|relaxation]], or happiness. This connection to pleasant emotions exists because it was advantageous to humans before today's society to be able to see far into the distance in a brightly lit vista. Similarly, visual images that are dark and/or obscure typically elicit emotions of [[anxiety]] and fear. This is because an impeded visual field is disadvantageous for a human to be able to defend itself.<ref name="carroll">{{cite journal | last1 = Carroll | first1 = N | year = 2003 | title = ART AND MOOD: PRELIMINARY NOTES AND CONJECTURES | url = | journal = Monist | volume = 86 | issue = 4| pages = 521–555 | doi=10.5840/monist200386426}}</ref>
=== Meta-Emotions === The optimal visual artwork creates what Noy & Noy-Sharav call "meta-emotions." These are multiple emotions that are triggered at the same time. They posit that what people see when immediately looking at a piece of artwork are the formal, technical qualities of the work and its complexity. Works that are well-made but lacking in appropriate complexity, or works that are intricate but missing in technical skill will not produce "meta-emotions."<ref name="noy">{{cite journal | last1 = Noy | first1 = P. | last2 = Noy-Sharav | first2 = D. | year = 2013 | title = Art and Emotions | url = | journal = International Journal of Applied Psychoanalytic Studies | volume = 10 | issue = 2| pages = 100–107 | doi = 10.1002/aps.1352 }}</ref> For example, seeing a perfectly painted chair (technical quality but no complexity) or a sloppily drawn image of [[Christ]] on the cross (complex but no skill) would be unlikely to stimulate deep emotional responses. However, beautifully painted works of Christ's [[crucifixion]] are likely make people who can relate or who understand the story behind it weep.
Noy & Noy-Sharav also claim that art is the most potent form of emotional communication. They cite examples of people being able to listen to and [[dance]] to [[music]] for hours without getting tired and literature being able to take people to far away, imagined lands inside their heads. Art forms give humans a higher satisfaction in emotional release than simply managing emotions on their own. Art allows people to have a cathartic release of pent-up emotions either by creating work or by witnessing and pseudo-experiencing what they see in front of them. Instead of being passive recipients of actions and images, art is intended for people to challenge themselves and work through the emotions they see presented in the artistic message ./..<ref name="noy" />
==Types of elicited emotions== {{Quote box |quote = Art is a human activity, consisting in this, that one man consciously, by means of certain external signs, hands on to others feelings he has lived through, and that other people are infected by these feeling and also experience them. |source = --[[Leo Tolstoy]], ''[[What Is Art?]]'' (1897)<ref name="Maude1902">{{cite book|last=Maude|first=Aylmer|title=Essays on art: I. An introduction to "What is art?"; II. Tolstoy's view of art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=17o8AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA34|accessdate=2 November 2012|year=1902|publisher=Grant Richards|page=34}}</ref> |width = 30% |align= right |bgcolor tions works of art can elicit; whether these are defined emotions such as anger, confusion or happiness, or a general feeling of aesthetic appreciation.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure>{{cite journal|last=Silvia|first=Paul J.|title=Looking past pleasure: Anger, confusion, disgust, pride, surprise, and other unusual aesthetic emotions.|journal=Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts|date=1 January 2009|volume=3|issue=1|pages=48–51|doi=10.1037/a0014632}}</ref> The aesthetic experience seems to be determined by liking or disliking a work of art, placed along a continuum of pleasure–displeasure.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> However, other diverse emotions can still be felt in response to art, which can be sorted into three categories: Knowledge Emotions, Hostile Emotions, and Self-Conscious Emotions.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure />
===Liking and comprehensibility === Pleasure elicited by works of art can also have multiple sources. A number of theories suggest that enjoyment of a work of art is dependent on its comprehensibility or ability to be understood easily.<ref name=Millis-titles>{{cite journal|last=Millis|first=Keith|title=Making meaning brings pleasure: The influence of titles on aesthetic experiences.|journal=Emotion|date=1 January 2001|volume=1|issue=3|pages=320–329|doi=10.1037/1528-3542.1.3.320|pmid=12934689}}</ref> Therefore, when more information about a work of art is provided, such as a title, description, or artist's statement, researchers predict that viewers will understand the piece better, and demonstrate greater liking for it.<ref name=Millis-titles /> Experimental evidence shows that the presence of a title for a work increases perceived understanding, regardless of whether that title is elaborative or descriptive.<ref name=Millis-titles /> Elaborative titles did affect aesthetic responses to the work, suggesting viewers were not creating alternative explanations for the works if an explaining title is given.<ref name=Millis-titles /> Descriptive or random titles do not show any of these effects.<ref name=Millis-titles />
Furthering the thought that pleasure in art derives from its comprehensibility and processing fluency, some authors have described this experience as an emotion.<ref name=Armstrong-Beauty>{{cite journal|last=Armstrong|first=Thomas|author2=Detweiler-Bedell, Brian|title=Beauty as an emotion: The exhilarating prospect of mastering a challenging world.|journal=Review of General Psychology|date=1 January 2008|volume=12|issue=4|pages=305–329|doi=10.1037/a0012558}}</ref> The emotional feeling of beauty, or an aesthetic experience, does not have a valence emotional undercurrent, rather is general cognitive arousal due to the fluent processing of a novel stimuli.<ref name=Armstrong-Beauty /> Some authors believe that aesthetic emotions is enough of a unique and verifiable experience that it should be included in general theories of emotion.<ref name=Armstrong-Beauty />
{{Quote box |quote = Art is the emotional expression of human personality. |source = --[[Eugène Véron]], ''L'Esthetique'' (1882)<ref>{{cite book|last=Véron|first=Eugène|title=L'Esthetique|year=1882|location=Paris|page=35|edition=1st|authorlink=Eugène Véron}}</ref> |width = 25% |align= left |bgcolor= #c6dbf7 }}
===Knowledge emotions=== Knowledge emotions deal with reactions to thinking and feeling, such as interest, confusion, and surprise.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> They often stem from self-analysis of what the viewer knows, expects, and perceives.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /><ref name=Silvia-confusion /> This set of emotions also spur actions that motivate further learning and thinking.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure />
====Interest==== Interest in a work of art arises from perceiving the work as new, complex, and unfamiliar, as well as understandable.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /><ref name=Silvia-confusion /> This dimension is studied most often by aesthetics researchers, and can be equated with aesthetic pleasure or an aesthetic experience.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> This stage of art experience usually occurs as the viewer understands the artwork they are viewing, and the art fits into their knowledge and expectations while providing a new experience.<ref name=Silvia-confusion />
====Confusion==== Confusion can be viewed as an opposite to interest, and serves as a signal to the self to inform the viewer that they cannot comprehend what they are looking at, and confusion often necessitates a shift in action to remedy the lack of understanding.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /><ref name=Silvia-confusion>{{cite journal|last=Silvia|first=Paul J.|title=Confusion and interest: The role of knowledge emotions in aesthetic experience.|journal=Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts|date=1 January 2010|volume=4|issue=2|pages=75–80|doi=10.1037/a0017081}}</ref> Confusion is thought to stem from uncertainty, and a lack of one's expectations and knowledge being met by a work of art.<ref name=Silvia-confusion /> Confusion is most often experienced by art novices, and therefore must often be dealt with by those in arts education.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure />
====Surprise==== Surprise functions as a disruption of current action to alert a viewer to a significant event.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> The emotion is centered around the experience of something new and unexpected, and can be ellicied by sensory incongruity.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> Art can ellicit surprise when expectations about the work are not met, but the work changes those expectations in an understandable way.
===Hostile emotions=== Hostile emotions toward art are often very visible in the form of anger or frustration, and can result in censorship, but are less easily described by a continuum of aesthetic pleasure-displeasure.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> These reactions center around the hostility triad: anger, disgust, and contempt.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> These emotions often motivate aggression, self-assertion, and violence, and arise from perception of the artist's deliberate trespass onto the expectations of the viewer.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure />
===Self-conscious emotions=== Self-conscious emotions are responses that reflect upon the self and one's actions, such as pride, guilt, shame, regret and embarrassment.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> These are much more complex emotions, and involve assessing events as agreeing with one's self-perception or not, and adjusting one's behavior accordingly.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure /> There are numerous instances of artists expressing self-conscious emotions in response to their art, and self-conscious emotions can also be felt collectively.<ref name=Silvia-lookingpastpleasure />
====Sublime feelings==== Researchers have investigated the experience of the sublime, viewed as similar to aesthetic appreciation, which causes general psychological arousal.<ref name=Eskine-sublime>{{cite journal|last=Eskine|first=Kendall J.|author2=Kacinik, Natalie A.|author3= Prinz, Jesse J.|title=Stirring images: Fear, not happiness or arousal, makes art more sublime.|journal=Emotion|date=1 January 2012|volume=12|issue=5|pages=1071–1074|doi=10.1037/a0027200}}</ref> The sublime feeling has been connected to a feeling of happiness in response to art, but may be more related to an experience of fear.<ref name=Eskine-sublime /> Researchers have shown that feelings of fear induced before looking at artwork results in more sublime feelings in response to those works.<ref name=Eskine-sublime />
====Aesthetic chills==== {{Main|Aesthetic chills}} Another common emotional response is that of chills when viewing a work of art. The feeling is predicted to be related to similar aesthetic experiences such as awe, feeling touched, or absorption.<ref name=Silvia-chills>{{cite journal|last=Silvia|first=Paul J.|author2=Nusbaum, Emily C.|title=On personality and piloerection: Individual differences in aesthetic chills and other unusual aesthetic experiences.|journal=Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts|date=1 January 2011|volume=5|issue=3|pages=208–214|doi=10.1037/a0021914}}</ref> Personality traits along the Big 5 Inventory have been shown to be predictors of a person's experience of aesthetic chills, especially a high rating on Openness to Experience.<ref name=Silvia-chills /> This counters the effect of fluid intelligence, where those with higher amounts of fluid intelligence are less likely to experience chills.<ref name=Silvia-chills /> Experience with the arts also predicts someone's experience of aesthetic chills, but this may be due to them experiencing art more frequently.<ref name=Silvia-chills />
===Effects of expertise=== The fact that art is analyzed and experienced differently by those with artistic training and expertise than those who are artistically naive has been shown numerous times. Researchers have tried to understand how experts interact with art so differently from the art naive, as experts tend to like more abstract compositions, and show a greater liking for both modern and classical types of art.<ref name=Leder-appreciated>{{cite journal|last=Leder|first=Helmut|author2=Gerger, Gernot|author3= Dressler, Stefan G.|author4= Schabmann, Alfred|title=How art is appreciated.|journal=Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts|date=1 January 2012|volume=6|issue=1|pages=2–10|doi=10.1037/a0026396}}</ref> Experts also exhibit more arousal when looking at modern and abstract works, while non-experts show more arousal to classical works.<ref name=Leder-appreciated />
Other researchers predicted that experts find more complex art interesting because they have changed their appraisals of art to create more interest, or are possibly making completely different types of appraisals than novices.<ref name=Silvia-expertise>{{cite journal|last=Silvia|first=Paul J.|title=Artistic training and interest in visual art: Applying the appraisal model of aesthetic emotions|journal=Empirical Studies of the Arts|year=2006|volume=24|issue=2|pages=139–161|doi=10.2190/dx8k-6wea-6wpa-fm84}}</ref> Experts described works rated high in complexity as easier to understand and more interesting than did novices, possibly as experts tend to use more idiosyncratic criteria when judging artworks.<ref name=Silvia-expertise /> However, experts seem to use the same appraisals of emotions that novices do, but these appraisals are at a higher level, because a wider range of art is comprehensible to experts.<ref name=Silvia-expertise />
====Expertise and museum visits==== Due to most art being in museums and galleries, most people have to make deliberate choices to interact with art. Researchers are interested in what types of experiences and emotions people are looking for when going to experience art in a museum.<ref name=Mastandera-muesum>{{cite journal|last=Mastandrea|first=Stefano|author2=Bartoli, G.|author3=Bove, G.|title=Learning through ancient art and experincing emotions with contemporary art: Comparing visits in two different museums|journal=Empirical Studies of the Arts|year=2007|volume=25|issue=2|pages=173–191|doi=10.2190/r784-4504-37m3-2370}}</ref> Most people respond that they visit museums to experience 'the pleasure of art' or 'the desire for cultural learning', but when broken down, visitors of museums of classical art are more motivated to see famous works and learn more about them.<ref name=Mastandera-muesum /> Visitors in contemporary art museums were more motivated by a more emotional connection to the art, and went more for the pleasure than a learning experience.<ref name=Mastandera-muesum /> Predictors of who would prefer to go to which type of museum lay in education level, art fluency, an socio-economic status.<ref name=Mastandera-muesum />
==Theories and models of elicited emotions== Researchers have offered a number of theories to describe emotional responses to art, often aligning with the various theories of the basis of emotions. Authors have argued that the emotional experience is created explicitly by the artist and mimicked in the viewer, or that the emotional experience of art is a by-product of the analysis of that work.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart /><ref name=Fellous-review />
===Appraisal theory=== The [[appraisal theory]] of emotions centers on the assumption that it is the evaluation of events, and not the events themselves, that cause emotional experiences.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart /> Emotions are then created by different groups of appraisal structures that events are analyzed through.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart /> When applied to art, appraisal theories argue that various artistic structures, such as complexity, prototypically, and understanding are used as appraisal structures, and works that show more typical art principles will create a stronger aesthetic experience .<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart /> Appraisal theories suggest that art is experienced as interesting after being analyzed through a novelty check and coping-potential check, which analyze the art's newness of experience for the viewer, and the viewer's ability to understand the new experience.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart /> Experimental evidence suggests that art is preferred when the viewer finds it easier to understand, and that interest in a work is predictable with knowledge of the viewer's ability to process complex visual works, which supports the appraisal theory.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart /> People with higher levels of artistic expertise and knowledge often prefer more complex works of art. Under appraisal theory, experts have a different emotional experience to art due to a preference for more complex works that they can understand better than a naive viewer.<ref name=Silvia-emotionalresponsestoart />
====Appraisal and negative emotions==== A newer take on this theory focuses on the consequences of the emotions elicited from art, both positive and negative. The original theory argues that positive emotions are the result of a biobehavioral reward system, where a person feels a positive emotion when they have completed a personal goal.<ref name=cooper-opposingart>{{cite journal|last=Cooper|first=Jessica M.|author2=Paul J. Silvia|title=Opposing art: Rejection as an action tendency of hostile aesthetic emotions|journal=Empirical Studies of the Arts|year=2009|volume=27|issue=1|pages=109–126|doi=10.2190/em.27.1.f}}</ref> These emotional rewards create actions by motivating approach or withdrawal from a stimuli, depending if the object is positive or negative to the person.<ref name=cooper-opposingart /> However, these theories have not often focused on negative emotions, especially negative emotional experiences from art.<ref name=cooper-opposingart /> These emotions are central to experimental aesthetics research in order to understand why people have negative, rejecting, condemning, or censoring reactions to works of art.<ref name=cooper-opposingart /> By showing research participants controversial photographs, rating their feelings of anger, and measuring their subsequent actions, researchers found that the participants that felt hostile toward the photographs displayed more rejection of the works.<ref name=cooper-opposingart /> This suggests that negative emotions towards a work of art can create a negative action toward it, and suggests the need for further research on negative reactions towards art.<ref name=cooper-opposingart />
===Minimal model=== Other psychologists believe that emotions are of minimal functionality, and are used to move a person towards incentives and away from threats.<ref name=Xenakis-functionalrole>{{cite journal|last=Xenakis|first=Ioannis|author2=Arnellos, Argyris|author3= Darzentas, John|title=The functional role of emotions in aesthetic judgment|journal=New Ideas in Psychology|date=1 August 2012|volume=30|issue=2|pages=212–226|doi=10.1016/j.newideapsych.2011.09.003}}</ref> Therefore, positive emotions are felt upon the attainment of a goal, and negative emotions when a goal has failed to be achieved.<ref name=Xenakis-functionalrole /> The basic states of pleasure or pain can be adapted to aesthetic experiences by a disinterested buffer, where the experience is not explicitly related to the goal-reaching of the person, but a similar experience can be analyzed from a disinterested distance.<ref name=Xenakis-functionalrole /> These emotions are disinterested because the work of art or artist's goals are not affecting the person's well being, but the viewer can feel whether or not those goals were achieved from a third-party distance.
===Five-step aesthetic experience=== Other theorists have focused their models on the disrupting and unique experience that comes from the interacting with a powerful work of art. An early model focused on a two-part experience: facile recognition and meta-cognitive perception, or the experience of the work of art and the mind's analysis of that experience.<ref name=Pelowski-5part>{{cite journal|last=Pelowski|first=Matthew|author2=Akiba, Fuminori|title=A model of art perception, evaluation and emotion in transformative aesthetic experience|journal=New Ideas in Psychology|date=1 August 2011|volume=29|issue=2|pages=80–97|doi=10.1016/j.newideapsych.2010.04.001}}</ref> A further cognitive model strengthens this idea into a five-part emotional experience of a work of art.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> As this five-part model is new, it remains only a theory, as not much empirical evidence for the model had been researched yet.
====Part one: Pre-expectations and self-image==== The first stage of this model focuses on the viewer's expectations of the work before seeing it, based on their previous experiences, their observational strategies, and the relation of the work to themselves.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> Viewers who tend to appreciate art, or know more about it will have different expectations at this stage than those who are not engaged by art.<ref name=Pelowski-5part />
====Part two: Cognitive mastery and introduction of discrepancy ==== After viewing the work of art, people will make an initial judgment and classification of the work, often based on their preconceptions of the work.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> After initial classification, viewers attempt to understand the motive and meaning of the work, which can then inform their perception of the work, creating a cycle of changing perception and the attempt to understand it.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> It is at this point any discrepancies between expectations and the work, or the work and understanding arise.<ref name=Pelowski-5part />
====Part three: Secondary control and escape==== When an individual finds a discrepancy in their understanding that cannot be resolved or ignored, they move to the third stage of their interaction with a work of art.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> At this point, interaction with the work has switched from lower-order and unconscious processes to higher-order cognitive involvement, and tension and frustration starts to be felt.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> In order to maintain their self-assumptions and to resolve the work, an individual will try to change their environment in order for the issue to be resolved or ignored.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> This can be done by re-classifying the work and its motives, blaming the discrepancy on an external source, or attempting to escape the situation or mentally withdraw from the work.<ref name=Pelowski-5part />
====Part four: Meta-cognitive reassessment==== If viewers cannot escape or reassess the work, they are forced to reassess the self and their interactions with works of art.<ref name=Pelowski-5part /> This experience of self-awareness through a work of art is often externally caused, rather than internally motivated, and starts a transformative process to understand the meaning of the discrepant work, and edit their own self-image.<ref name=Pelowski-5part />
====Part five: Aesthetic outcome and new mastery==== After the self-transformation and change in expectations, the viewer resets their interaction with the work, and begins the process anew with deeper self-understanding and cognitive mastery of the artwork.<ref name=Pelowski-5part />
==Pupillary response tests== In order to research emotional responses to art, researchers often rely on behavioral data.<ref name=Leder-pupil>{{cite journal|last=Kuchinke|first=Lars|author2=Trapp, Sabrina|author3= Jacobs, Arthur M.|author4= Leder, Helmut|title=Pupillary responses in art appreciation: Effects of aesthetic emotions.|journal=Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts|date=1 January 2009|volume=3|issue=3|pages=156–163|doi=10.1037/a0014464}}</ref> But new psychophysilogical methods of measuring emotional response are beginning to be used, such as the measurement of pupillary response.<ref name=Leder-pupil /> Pupil responses have been predicted to indicate image pleasantness and emotional arousal, but can be confounded by luminance, and confusion between an emotion's positive or negative valence, requiring an accompanying verbal explanation of emotional state.<ref name=Rembrandt>{{cite journal|last=Powell|first=W. Ryan|author2=Schirillo, James A.|title=Hemispheric laterality measured in Rembrandt's portraits using pupil diameter and aesthetic verbal judgements|journal=Cognition & Emotion|date=1 August 2011|volume=25|issue=5|pages=868–885|doi=10.1080/02699931.2010.515709}}</ref> Pupil dilatations have been found to predict emotional responses and the amount of information the brain is processing, measures important in testing emotional response ellicted by artwork.<ref name=Leder-pupil /> Further, the existence of pupillary responses to artwork can be used as an argument that art does ellicit emotional responses with physiological reactions.<ref name=Leder-pupil /> [[File:Juan Gris 004.jpg|thumb|An example Cubist work by Juan Gris]]
===Pupil responses to art=== After viewing Cubist paintings of varying complexity, abstraction, and familiarity, participants' pupil responses were greatest when viewing aesthetically pleasing artwork, and highly accessible art, or art low in abstraction.<ref name=Leder-pupil /> Pupil responses also correlated with personal preferences of the cubist art.<ref name=Leder-pupil /> High pupil responses were also correlated with faster cognitive processing, supporting theories that aesthetic emotions and preferences are related to the brain's ease of processing the stimuli.<ref name=Leder-pupil />
====Left-cheek biases==== [[File:Rembrandt - Minerva - WGA19246.jpg|thumb|''Minerva'' Rembrandt. Female portrait showing left-cheek orientation]] These effects are also seen when investigating the Western preference for left-facing portraits. This skew towards left-cheek is found in the majority of Western portraits, and is rated as more pleasing than other portrait orientations.<ref name=Blackburn-pupil>{{cite journal|last=Blackburn|first=Kelsey|author2=Schirillo, James|title=Emotive hemispheric differences measured in real-life portraits using pupil diameter and subjective aesthetic preferences|journal=Experimental Brain Research|date=19 April 2012|volume=219|issue=4|pages=447–455|doi=10.1007/s00221-012-3091-y}}</ref> Theories for this preference suggest that the left side of the face as more emotionally descriptive and expressive, which lets viewers connect to this emotional content better.<ref name=Blackburn-pupil /> Pupil response tests were used to test emotional response to different types of portraits, left or right cheek, and pupil dilation was linearly related to the pleasantness of the portrait, with increased dilations for pleasant images, and constrictions for unpleasant images.<ref name=Blackburn-pupil /> Left-facing portraits were rated as more pleasant, even when mirrored to appear right-facing, suggesting that people are more attracted to more emotional facial depictions.<ref name=Blackburn-pupil />
This research was continued, using portraits by [[Rembrandt]] featuring females with a left-cheek focus and males with a right-cheek focus.<ref name=Rembrandt /> Researchers predicted Rembrandt chose to portray his subjects this way to elicit different emotional responses in his viewers related to which portrait cheek was favored.<ref name=Rembrandt /> In comparison to previous studies, increased pupil size was only found for male portraits with a right-cheek preference. This may be because the portraits were viewed as domineering, and the subsequent pupil response was due to unpleasantness.<ref name=Rembrandt /> As pupil dilation is more indicative of strength of emotional response than the valence, a verbal description of emotional responses should accompany further pupillary response tests.<ref name=Rembrandt />
==Art as emotional regulation== Art is also used as an emotional regulator, most often in [[Art Therapy]] sessions. Studies have shown that creating art can serve as a method of short-term [[mood (psychology)|mood]] regulation.<ref name=Drake-venting>{{cite journal|last=Drake|first=Jennifer E.|author2=Winner, Ellen|title=Confronting sadness through art-making: Distraction is more beneficial than venting.|journal=Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts|date=1 January 2012|volume=6|issue=3|pages=255–261|doi=10.1037/a0026909}}</ref><ref name=Dalebroux-venting>{{cite journal|last=Dalebroux|first=Anne|author2=Goldstein, Thalia R.|author3= Winner, Ellen|title=Short-term mood repair through art-making: Positive emotion is more effective than venting|journal=Motivation and Emotion|volume=32|issue=4|pages=288–295|doi=10.1007/s11031-008-9105-1}}</ref> This type of regulation falls into two categories: venting and distraction.<ref name=Drake-venting /> Artists in all fields of the arts have reported emotional venting and distraction through the creation of their art.<ref name=Drake-venting /><ref name=Dalebroux-venting />
===Venting=== Venting through art is the process of using art to attend to and discharge negative emotions.<ref name=Drake-venting /> However, research has shown venting to be a less effective method of emotional regulation. Research participants asked to draw either an image related to a sad movie they just watched, or a neutral house, demonstrated less negative mood after the neutral drawing.<ref name=Drake-venting /> Venting drawings did improve negative mood more than no drawing activity.<ref name=Drake-venting /> Other research suggests that this is because analyzing negative emotions can have a helpful effect, but immersing in negative emotions can have a deleterious effect.<ref name=Dalebroux-venting />
===Distraction=== Distraction is the process of creating art to oppose, or in spite of negative emotions.<ref name=Drake-venting /> This can also take the form of fantasizing, or creating an opposing positive to counteract a negative affect.<ref name=Dalebroux-venting /> Research has demonstrated that distractive art making activities improve mood greater than venting activities.<ref name=Drake-venting /> Distractive drawings were shown to decrease negative emotions more than venting drawings or no drawing task even after participants were asked to recall their saddest personal memories.<ref name=Drake-venting /> These participants also experienced an increase in positive affect after a distractive drawing task.<ref name=Drake-venting /> The change in mood valence after a distractive drawing task is even greater when participants are asked to create happy drawings to counter their negative mood.<ref name=Dalebroux-venting />
==See also== * [[Emotionalism (disorder)|Emotionalism]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * {{cite IEP |url-id=art-emot |title=Art and Emotion}} * {{cite journal|last=Ducasse|first=C. J.|title=Art and the Language of the Emotions|journal=The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism|date=Autumn 1964|volume=23|issue=1|pages=109–112|jstor=428143}} *{{cite book|last=Silver|first=Rawley|title=Art as Language: Access to Emotions and Cognitive Skills through Drawings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0vwsNBRo7awC|date=12 January 2001|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-58391-051-1}}
[[Category:Aesthetics]] [[Category:Emotion]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2013}}
{{more citations needed|date=June 2014}} '''Artex''' (Art Expo Fair) began in 1986 in Auckland, New Zealand in 1986 and ran until 1994. It was the first art fair to be held in New Zealand which showcased historical and contemporary New Zealand art.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Artex was the genesis for what is now known as the Auckland Art Fair.
== History == The first Artex, titled ARTEX 86 was held from 27 – 31 August 1986 at the Princes Wharf Passenger Terminal Building in Auckland New Zealand. The first Artex event was opened by the Minister of Arts, The Right Honourable [[Margaret Austin]] and former chair-person of The Arts Council (now [[Creative New Zealand]]) [[Hamish Keith|Mr Hamish Keith]]. The fair included 33 dealer galleries, groups and individual artists including the [[:Category:People associated with the Auckland Society of Arts|Auckland Society of the Arts]]. The event also featured demonstrations and videos of prominent New Zealand artists such as [[Philip Clairmont]], loaned by the [[Auckland Art Gallery]].<ref name="Art New Zealand">{{cite journal|last=Daly-Peoples|first=John|title=Artex 86|journal=Art New Zealand|year=1986/7|volume=41|issue=Summer|pages=36|accessdate=}}</ref> The organizer [[Warwick Henderson]],<ref name=WarwickHenderson>{{cite web|title=About: Warwick Henderson Gallery|url=http://www.warwickhenderson.co.nz/about/|website=Warwick Henderson Gallery|publisher=Warwick Henderson Gallery|ref=Warwick Henderson}}</ref> a businessman, art collector and investment art dealer was concerned that New Zealand contemporary artists failed to receive the recognition they deserved because artists and their dealers simply failed to actively promote and sell their work. This lack of promotion of contemporary New Zealand art to a New Zealand audience was the motivation behind New Zealand’s first Art Fair. Henderson stated at the time, "there is a perception art is for the elite only and many potential buyers feel intimidated visiting dealer galleries. I am hoping to break down these barriers and make art accessible for all." <ref name="Stephen Christensen reports on Artex 86 exhibition in Auckland">{{cite news|last=Christensen|first=Steven|title=Art Fair 27th August 1986|newspaper=TV One 6.30pm News|date=27 August 1986}}</ref>
Arts writer [[John Daly-Peoples]] stated ‘there is an underlying belief that good art will sell itself and that the number of people who pass through the gallery is not really relevant.' ‘While tens of thousands might attend a well promoted exhibition some smaller dealer galleries count attendance in dozens.' While 'there are no exhibitions of ''New Zealand'' art attracting people in their tens of thousands.'<ref name="Art New Zealand" /> The blockbuster exhibitions in New Zealand were public institution arranged exhibitions such as [[Monet]], [[Henry Moore]] and ‘Te Maori’ (a traveling exhibition of traditional Maori carvings and artifacts that eventually traveled internationally). New Zealand contemporary art shows had never gained this level of attention.
Despite this the Artex art fair’s inaugural event in 1986 attracted unprecedented crowds, with a ‘steady stream of visitors’ and attendance records for the first show reaching 12,000 <ref name="New Zealand Herald">{{cite news|title=Over 12,000 visit Art Fair|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|date=1 September 1986}}</ref> The show itself sold around $300,000 worth of art work.<ref name="New Zealand Herald" /> There was also significant media attention surrounding Artex, with a report on the fair on television NZ headline 6pm News.<ref name="Stephen Christensen reports on Artex 86 exhibition in Auckland" /> The New Zealand Herald also featured ARTEX in an article on 1 September headed ‘Over 12,000 visit Art Fair.’<ref name="New Zealand Herald" /> There were several radio interviews including a comprehensive interview with the organizer on Radio New Zealand's National Program. The first fair was also subject to some controversy when with [[Leighton Smith (radio)|Leighton Smith]], host of New Zealand's leading radio show, [[Newstalk ZB]] complained on air that he had to spend $10 for entry. The organizer also criticized the Arts Council of New Zealand for failing to support the show by way of funding or a grant.
== New Zealand Art Market ==
Artex marked a change in New Zealand’s art market,{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} with a more direct concentration on the ‘business of art,’ as it not only put a focus on New Zealand Artists - celebrating modern New Zealand work as well as its historical art heritage, it revealed contemporary New Zealand paintings by leading New Zealand artists such as [[Colin McCahon]], [[Toss Woollaston]], [[Michael Smither]], [[John Weeks (painter)|John Weeks]], Allen Maddox, Keith Patterson, [[Philip Clairmont]], [[Frances Hodgkins]], [[Ian Scott (artist)|Ian Scott]], [[Dick Frizzell]] and [[Dean Buchanan]]. For the many thousands of visitors it was their first live exposure to serious New Zealand contemporary art.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} ARTEX paved the way for contemporary art in New Zealand to become more mainstream and accessible to the general public and budding art collectors.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Owing to the success of the first ARTEX in 1986, further shows were held in Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch. Artex (Art Fairs) TM, currently owned by DMG Group.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
[[Category:Arts in New Zealand]] [[Category:Art fairs]]

{{Infobox geographical indication | name = Bastar Iron Craft | color = Blue | logo = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | alternative names = | description = <!-- Describe in brief --> | type = Handicraft | area = [[Bastar district]], [[Chhattisgarh]] | country = India | registered = 2008–2009 | material = Iron | official website = <!-- {{URL|wwww.example.org}} --> }} '''Bastar Iron Craft''' (also known as "Wrought iron craft of Baster") is a traditional Indian [[iron]] crafts that are manufactured in the [[Bastar district|Bastar]] district of [[Chhattisgarh]] state, [[India]]. The iron-crafting work has been protected under the [[geographical indication]] (GI) of the [[Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights]] (TRIPS) agreement. It is listed at item 82 as "Bastar Iron Craft" of the GI Act 1999 of the Government of India with registration confirmed by the Controller General of Patents Designs and Trademarks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ipindia.nic.in/girindia/treasures_protected/registered_GI_18November2015.pdf|title=State Wise Registration Details Of G.I Applications|accessdate=5 July 2016|publisher=Controller General of Patents Designs and Trademarks|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201065403/http://ipindia.nic.in/girindia/treasures_protected/registered_GI_18November2015.pdf|archivedate=1 February 2016|df=}}</ref>
The iron craft skill is passed through generation to generation in Bastar region. Some tribal communities are experts in iron craft work and many of them became as iron-smiths. Among many communities [[Gondi people|Gondi]] and [[Madiya language|Maria]] are notable for the traditional iron-crafting.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dsource.in/resource/wrought-iron-craft-bastar/history | title=/ Wrought Iron Craft of Bastar - History | accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of Geographical Indications in India]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
;Bibliography * {{cite book | title=Tribal arts and crafts of Madhya Pradesh | publisher=Mapin Publishing | author=Manohar, Aashi | year=1996 | pages=142 | isbn=0-944142-71-0}} * {{cite book | title=The India Magazine of Her People and Culture, Volume 7 | publisher=A. H. Advani | year=1986 | pages=142 }}
== External links == * [http://www.idc.iitb.ac.in/dsource/gallery/wrought-iron-craft-bastar Design Gallery: Wrought Iron craft of Bastar]
